articles.headline: High-Speed Rail Poised to Alter China
articles.snippet: Beyond controversies and cost concerns, high-speed trains are reducing hurdles posed by China’s size, bringing benefits in tow and posing challenges for the country’s competitors.
articles.abstract: Beyond controversies and cost concerns, high-speed trains are reducing hurdles posed by China’s size, bringing benefits in tow and posing challenges for the country’s competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHANGSHA, China — Even as China prepares to open bullet train service from Beijing to Shanghai by July 1, this nation’s steadily expanding high-speed rail network is being pilloried on a scale rare among Chinese citizens and news media.

articles.headline: Fed to Defer New Efforts for Growth
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said it would complete a planned purchase of $600 billion in Treasury securities next week as scheduled.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said it would complete a planned purchase of $600 billion in Treasury securities next week as scheduled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — And at the end of June, the Federal Reserve finished its work and rested.

articles.headline: Derivatives Cloud the Possible Fallout From a Greek Default
articles.snippet: Regulators worry that derivatives that insure against a default may have dangerously concentrated the risks.
articles.abstract: Regulators worry that derivatives that insure against a default may have dangerously concentrated the risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the $616 billion question: Does the euro crisis have a hidden A.I.G.?

articles.headline: Apple’s Final Cut Is Dead. Long Live Final Cut.
articles.snippet: Apple substituted one Final Cut video-editing program for another, and the upgraded version covers nearly all the bases.
articles.abstract: Apple substituted one Final Cut video-editing program for another, and the upgraded version covers nearly all the bases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple’s Final Cut Pro is the leading video-editing program. It’s a $1,000 professional app. It was used to make “The Social Network,” “True Grit,” “Eat Pray Love” and thousands of student movies, independent films and TV shows. According to the research firm SCRI, it has 54 percent of the video-editing market, far more than its rivals from Adobe and Avid.

articles.headline: Obama Will Speed Pullout From War in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: President Obama said that the “tide of war is receding” and, in an acknowledgment of domestic economic strains, that “it is time to focus on nation-building here at home.”
articles.abstract: President Obama said that the “tide of war is receding” and, in an acknowledgment of domestic economic strains, that “it is time to focus on nation-building here at home.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared Wednesday that the United States had largely achieved its goals in Afghanistan, setting in motion a substantial withdrawal of American troops in an acknowledgment of the shifting threat in the region and the fast-changing political and economic landscape in a war-weary America.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Some Greeks Fear Government Is Selling Nation
articles.snippet: The crown jewels of Greece’s socialist state are now likely to go to the highest bidder.
articles.abstract: The crown jewels of Greece’s socialist state are now likely to go to the highest bidder.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — They are the crown jewels of Greece’s socialist state, and they are now likely to go to the highest bidder: the ports of Piraeus and Thessaloniki; prime Mediterranean real estate; the national lottery; Greek Telecom; the postal bank and the national railway system.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: A Start-Up Matures, Working With AmEx
articles.snippet: American Express cardholders will receive discounts at certain shops and restaurants on their cellphone through an alliance with Foursquare.
articles.abstract: American Express cardholders will receive discounts at certain shops and restaurants on their cellphone through an alliance with Foursquare.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the New York start-up Foursquare Labs made its debut in 2009, it quickly began popularizing the idea of “checking in,” or using a cellphone application to tell friends that you are at a particular restaurant, bar or park.

articles.headline: Family Act Extends Reign in Las Vegas, With a Bit Less Glitter
articles.snippet: Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas is leaving office next month, but since his wife is the mayor-elect, he won’t be going far.
articles.abstract: Mayor Oscar B. Goodman of Las Vegas is leaving office next month, but since his wife is the mayor-elect, he won’t be going far.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Oscar B. Goodman, the mayor, loves to gamble. “Every single waking moment of my life,” he said. Carolyn Goodman, his wife, has not been near a gambling table in 30 years.

articles.headline: As Greece Ponders Default, Lessons From Argentina
articles.snippet: The effects of Argentina 2001 debt crisis still linger, and the country’s default at the time is still keeping it away from the global credit market.
articles.abstract: The effects of Argentina 2001 debt crisis still linger, and the country’s default at the time is still keeping it away from the global credit market.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — A decade ago, as Argentina slid toward financial collapse, banks barricaded themselves behind sheet metal to keep out protesters demanding access to their life savings.
articles.byline: By Charles Newbery and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: Global Oil Reserves Tapped in Effort to Cut Cost at Pump
articles.snippet: To replace some of the oil production lost during the Libya conflict, 60 million barrels will be released, with half coming from America’s reserves.
articles.abstract: To replace some of the oil production lost during the Libya conflict, 60 million barrels will be released, with half coming from America’s reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and its allies will release 60 million barrels of emergency oil reserves to replace lost Libyan oil production and assure adequate supplies for the summer, officials announced on Thursday.
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: A Nosedive Eases a Bit in Volatile U.S. Trading
articles.snippet: The Dow Jones industrial average ended a dramatic day a bit lower than where it started on slow growth, Europe’s debt crisis and the use of oil reserves.
articles.abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average ended a dramatic day a bit lower than where it started on slow growth, Europe’s debt crisis and the use of oil reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was another day of gyrations on Wall Street.

articles.headline: Long Elusive, Mob Legend Ended Up a Recluse
articles.snippet: After a decade of living a quiet life in California, James (Whitey) Bulger and his girlfriend appeared in court in Boston on Friday.
articles.abstract: After a decade of living a quiet life in California, James (Whitey) Bulger and his girlfriend appeared in court in Boston on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Charlie and Carol Gasko seemed to be just another fading, elderly couple enjoying retirement in a modest apartment building a few blocks from the Pacific in Santa Monica. He told a neighbor he had emphysema and spent his days lying on the couch watching television. Carol would venture out for strolls on the nearby Third Street Promenade, stopping by the Saturday Farmers’ Market or feeding a neighborhood stray cat. Often, he tagged along.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Abby Goodnough
